title: The Complete Guide to All 12 English Tenses
subtitle: Structure • Examples • Explanations

sections.heading: The Simple Tenses
sections.description: Used for habits, repeated actions, states (situations, opinions, feelings), and sometimes single actions.

subsections.title: Grammatical Structures
structure: Present Simple: Subject + Base Verb (Verb 1)
Past Simple: Subject + Past Simple Verb (Verb 2)
Future Simple: Subject + will + Base Verb
examples: I work. She works. (Present)
I worked. She worked. (Past)
I will work. She will work. (Future)
subsections.explanation: For he/she/it in Present Simple, add -s or -es. The verb 'be' has special forms: I am, you are, he/she/it is, etc.

subsections.title: Uses and Examples
structure: Habits & Repeated Actions
States (Situations, Opinions, Feelings)
Single Actions (Past & Future only)
Scheduled Events (Present only)
examples: I wake up at 6 am every day. (Present habit)
I have long hair. Doug is our team leader. (Present states)
I made an omelette yesterday. (Past single action)
Our train leaves at 9:00 PM. (Scheduled future)
subsections.explanation: Simple tenses describe permanent situations, habits, or facts. For scheduled events we can't control, use Present Simple.

sections.heading: The Continuous Tenses
sections.description: Describe temporary actions happening during a specific period. Often used for background actions.

subsections.title: Grammatical Structures
structure: Present Continuous: Subject + am/are/is + Verb-ing
Past Continuous: Subject + was/were + Verb-ing
Future Continuous: Subject + will be + Verb-ing
examples: I am talking to you. (Present)
I was talking to you. (Past)
I will be talking to you. (Future)
subsections.explanation: Continuous tenses show actions in progress at specific times.

subsections.title: Uses and Examples
structure: Temporary Actions at Specific Times
Background Actions (often interrupted)
Future Plans (Present Continuous only)
examples: Yesterday at 2 PM, I was talking to you. (Past temporary)
I was holding coffee when my son bumped into me. (Background)
Tomorrow we are flying to Rome. (Definite future plan)
subsections.explanation: Use for temporary situations and actions in progress. Present Continuous for definite personal plans.

subsections.title: Stative Verbs - CRITICAL RULE
structure: Stative verbs are NOT used in continuous tenses
Common stative verbs: want, know, love, hate, need, prefer, believe, own, understand
examples: ❌ I am wanting breakfast. (Incorrect)
✅ I want breakfast. (Correct)
❌ The students were knowing the answers. (Incorrect)
✅ The students knew the answers. (Correct)
subsections.explanation: Stative verbs describe states (thoughts, emotions, possession, senses) and cannot be used in continuous forms.

sections.heading: The Perfect Tenses
sections.description: Emphasize an action that happened BEFORE another point in time.

subsections.title: Grammatical Structures
structure: Present Perfect: Subject + have/has + Past Participle (Verb 3)
Past Perfect: Subject + had + Past Participle (Verb 3)
Future Perfect: Subject + will have + Past Participle (Verb 3)
examples: I have eaten. (Present Perfect)
I had eaten. (Past Perfect)
I will have eaten. (Future Perfect)
subsections.explanation: Perfect tenses focus on the relationship between actions in time.

subsections.title: Uses and Examples
structure: Emphasis on 'Before Another Point'
Past vs. Present Perfect Comparison
Actions Continuing Up to a Point
examples: I have been to Paris. (Before now - experience)
I had been to Paris before university. (Before past action)
By 2025, I will have lived here 22 years. (Continues to future point)
subsections.explanation: Present Perfect: experience relevant to present. Past Simple: specific time important. Perfect tenses show continuation.

sections.heading: The Perfect Continuous Tenses
sections.description: Emphasize the DURATION (how long) of an action that continues up to another point.

subsections.title: Grammatical Structures
structure: Present Perfect Continuous: Subject + have/has been + Verb-ing
Past Perfect Continuous: Subject + had been + Verb-ing
Future Perfect Continuous: Subject + will have been + Verb-ing
examples: The pie has been baking for 20 minutes. (Present)
The pie had been baking for 20 minutes. (Past)
The pie will have been baking for 20 minutes. (Future)
subsections.explanation: Perfect Continuous tenses emphasize the ongoing duration of an action.

subsections.title: Present Perfect Simple vs. Continuous
structure: Step 1: Is the verb STATIVE? → Use Present Perfect Simple
Step 2: Is the verb DYNAMIC? → Choose:
- Completed action → Present Perfect Simple
- Ongoing action → Present Perfect Continuous
examples: I have been a nurse since 2015. (Stative verb 'be')
The guests have eaten the main course. (Completed action)
The guests have been eating for two hours. (Ongoing action)
subsections.explanation: Use this decision process to choose between Simple and Continuous perfect forms.

subsections.title: Core Concepts
structure: Simple Tenses: Habits, states, facts (Permanent feeling)
Continuous Tenses: Temporary actions in progress (Background)
Perfect Tenses: Action BEFORE another point in time
Perfect Continuous: DURATION of action up to another point
examples: I work every day. (Simple - habit)
I am working right now. (Continuous - temporary)
I have worked here before. (Perfect - before now)
I have been working for hours. (Perfect Continuous - duration)
subsections.explanation: Each tense category serves a specific purpose in showing time relationships and action types.

tensesTable.example: I will be working at 5 PM.
I had worked there before I moved.
I will have worked 8 hours by 5 PM.
I have been working for hours.
I had been working for hours.
I will have been working for hours.
